//notes: the density given in sources is for a related chemical compound, of which poliglecarpone 25 (aka Monocryl) is a monomer
it's not unlikely that the monomer would have a noticable change in density
this is as close as we have so far
for the purposes of the amount of charges, we assume that an average wound is 50 mm in length
from that, placing 6 stitches roughly 10 mm apart yields 300 mm of suture required per wound
we assume this, rather than the stated 18 in. ≈ 457 mm to be the length of a single instance of suture
description: A length of thin, clear polymer that is used as medical thread for wound closure.  This suture is made of Monocryl: an absorbable material that will completely dissipate after a few weeks after being used.  Can be used along with a suture needle to close skin wounds.
//weight: volume per instance (5.3 µl) × density (1.07 g/cm3) = 5.67 mg ≈ 6 mg
